Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I had my first appt with my oncologist yesterday. What I have had so far is a lumpectomy and 4 lymph nodes removed on 30 Nov 13. Surgeon had said there were clear margins and no lymph node involvement so was expecting to arrange my tanning sessions and discuss hormone therapy. The oncologist dropped a bombshell by offering chemo as well. It's third generation regimen which he said is quite harsh using Docetaxel and Cyclophosphamide for 4 cycles. My tumour (invasive ductal carcinoma)  was 21mm, grade 2 and although the lymph nodes were 'clear' there are some isolated tumour cells in one of them.  We went through the PREDICT tool and with no treatment 10 year survival is 89%, rising to 91% with hormone therapy and to 94% with hormone therapy and chemo. Although he has offered me the chemo, he said that most patients in the same situation don't opt to have it.  I am trying to get my head around this and have another appt on 5th Feb to discuss my decision. I know chemo isn't a walk in the park but I've read so many threads on here that it is doable. Has anyone else been in this situation? If so, did you choose to have chemo or not? I would especially like to hear from anyone on these particular chemo drugs. Many thanks, Mudge x

Plus, like you, I want to give myself the best chance of survival.  My hubby is very supportive and already does much of the work around the house and I've got some good friends too to help me through so I think I will cope especially with everyone on this forum to help and advise me. Oh lovely, a new car. What have you got? Claire, thanks for letting me know that you are managing to work full time and care for your 3 year old whilst doing chemo. You are an inspiration! I hope I can sail through it too.  Many thanks everyone, Mudge x

Posts.Content: Hi H, My consultant said that Lobular Carcinoma In Situ is a misnomer and isn't cancer although there is a very slim chance it may develop into cancer years later. Most never develop any further.  Here is a link to what is on the Macland site about it http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Cancertypes/Breast/Aboutbreastcancer/Typesandrelatedconditions/Typesandrelatedconditions.aspx#DynamicJumpMenuManager_4_Anchor_2  and there's more info here http://www.breastcancercare.org.uk/breast-cancer-information/breast-awareness/benign-breast-conditions/lobular-neoplasia-lcis  My patch of LCIS showed up as an area of calcified specks (white on the mammogram and black on ultrasound). I saw the xrays they took during the biopsy and even though the screen was magnified approx x 10 the specks were only about 2mm across, so very tiny. They were between 1.5 and 2 cm depth below the skin. I had  been told I will need an annual mammogram before this patch was found so I'm assuming I won't need one any more often than that now. The xray guided biopsy required 2 mammographers and a radiologist. It was like having a mammogram but they sat me in a chair and wheeled me up to the machine. Then they compressed my breast, just like with an ordinary mammogram. The upper plate is different, metal with a large hole in it. They then took a couple of xrays to make sure the tiny area they selected was central below the hole in the plate, then they took two more, one from each side to determine the depth. Once they had pinpointed it I was given a local anaesthetic to the area and the biopsy needle is loaded onto the machine and guided by the computer. It sounds worse than it is. I really didn't feel anything and the radiologist took 7 samples, all through the 1 entry point. They xrayed the samples so I was told straight away that they had what they wanted. They also took one final xray of the area after the samples were removed (probably for their spot the difference competition lol!!) I think it all took about 20-30 mins altogether. I went back 11 days later for the results but as cancer hadn't been found my consultant has ordered further testing on the samples and didn't have those results then. I got them a week later. As I had prepared myself in case it was DCIS which would have meant a mastectomy because the 2 sites were about 5 inches apart, I was relieved to find out this area didn't need treatment. I had my lumpectomy last Friday and was home on Saturday afternoon. I was really pleased that I had so much more movement in my arm than I expected. The district nurse has made her 2nd visit today and I have had my dressings off and I can drive again for short journeys which is great as it means I don't have to get hubby to drive me to the farm down the road to feed my horse. Keep in touch and let me know when you hear about your biopsy. Best Wishes, Fiona x

Posts.Title: Undiagnosed and waiting………..

Posts.Content: Hi, Waiting is often the worst part so sorry you are going through this. I have had 2 biopsies. The first was guided by ultrasound to confirm I had invasive cancer when they found a 2cm lump. A few weeks later, before my op, the radiologist found another area, a patch of tiny white specks so I had a 2nd biopsy. The specks were too small to locate using ultrasound so I had an xray guided biopsy. This is more fiddly and time consuming but completely painless. I was told it may or may not be cancer. Fortunately, the results showed this area was only LCIS which isn't actually cancer and doesn't need treatment, just monitoring.  You may be in a similar position and because it was late afternoon it was too late to arrange.  I hope you will hear something soon.  Fx

Posts.Title: First post

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, I joined the group a couple of weeks ago and have been reading all the posts on here. I was feeling a bit of a voyeur just reading posts so thought I'd better introduce myself... It's good to know that someone has been through it all before and you are all marvellously supportive of each other.  I only knew something was wrong when I got called back for more tests following my first routine breast screening at the end of September (6 days after my 50th birthday).  A biopsy showed I had ductal invasive breast cancer under 2cm in my right breast. I was scheduled for a lumpectomy on 8th November but when I saw the Radiologist to have the guide wire inserted he found a second patch on the same breast. Surgery was postponed and I had another biopsy instead. I waited 3 weeks for the results and fortunately the new area was LCIS so didn't need treatment, just monitoring.  I finally had my lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy on Friday and will get the results on the 18th Dec.  I feel so lucky that my cancer was picked up so quickly and that everything happens so fast. It is just the waiting in between that gets to me a bit.

I've kept at my part time job but have also been getting plenty of R & R in this lovely sunshine. Keep positive, Mudge x
